messages.text:
> I think it isn't such a good idea to be so fuzzy about the criteria for being welcome.
Thanks for the input Kristoffer. I think the main motivation for our phrasing is this: this tweet is sent within the julia sphere and what this is basically saying is: "if you feel underrepresented in the julia community due to your gender, come to this event." -- two follow up questions here:

(1) what about the invitation to people outside the "julia sphere"? Yes, you have a point, if you don't know the julia community, you won't be able to answer that question with 100% confidence, and in retrospect, I think the phrasing could have been better there. But to speak from my own experiences: as a woman, if I read a similar tweet from say the machine learning community (say an ML conference), I will feel welcome to attend such event.
(2) why not exactly specify who is welcome? Well, that is tricky. Stating things like "non-male", "women/girls", "women and others", "women, transgender and non-binary" is each non inclusive in its own way.

TLDR: we're trying to say: you know the julia community... if you feel underrepresented in the julia community due to your gender please join us.

Issue is: what about the people who aren't part of the community and we specifically extended an invitation to them... Yes, in retrospect: some stats could have gone along with this tweet so that if the "you know the julia community" phrase is not the case above, then you can get that information and make the decision for yourself. I think we should try to include something like that next time.

> why not exactly specify who is welcome? Well, that is tricky. Stating things like "non-male", "women/girls", "women and others", "women, transgender and non-binary" is each non inclusive in its own way.
But surely, the point of adding the part about welcome and unwelcome genders in the invitation is, at least to some extent, to limit inclusivity. There are of course perfectly good reasons for that (e.g. promotes inclusivity in the long run) and I think no one really has a problem with it. I personally think it is fine to "embrace" the non-inclusivity and just state explicitly that the meeting is for non-males if that is what you guys had in mind when creating it.

messages.text:
> Stating things like "non-male", "women/girls", "women and others", "women, transgender and non-binary" is each non inclusive in its own way.
<@U6S2GUM43> presents a great point here. "Non-male" doesn't exactly clarify who is invited either, since we'd also like to include transmen, masculine-presenting non-binary people, and so on. Additionally, it shifts the focus away from the goal of creating a safe space for under-represented genders: the point is not to exclude cisgendered men, but to signal marginalized communities are more than welcomed here. The implementation detail should not be emphasized over the semantics of the event's intention.

attachments.title: Petrie multiplier
attachments.text:
The Petrie multiplier is a thought experiment
or mathematical model
invented by British computer scientist Karen Petrie, and first described by Ian Gent in 2013.
The multiplier "shows that if the percentage of men and women in the room who make questionable remarks to the other sex is equal and the percentage of women in the room is lower than the percentage of men, then the average woman experiences far more sexist comments than the average man."

messages.text: Thanks to everyone's feedback here. Please know that this was a collective decision from multiple people working on this initiative whose gender is underrepresented in the Julia community, and the choice to use "underrepresented genders" came with the sole purpose of welcoming to _all_ underrepresented genders. The call is happening today and I will try and bring up the question on the language we used -- hopefully things will only get better for next time.
